perturbation.original_text:
(b)
Price in Extension Periods. In the event that Customer elects to extend the Initial Term of the Agreement or of a Facility Addendum,
the Price for each applicable Product in any Extension Period shall be one hundred percent (100%) of Manufacturer’s Standard
Product Materials Cost plus one hundred and ten percent (110%) of Manufacturer’s Standard Conversion Cost of such Product, each
for the initial Fiscal Year of the first Extension Period with respect to such Product. During each Extension Period, the Price of such
Product may be adjusted as set forth in Section 3.2; provided that the initial Fiscal Year of the first Extension Period shall operate as
the Facility Conversion Cost Baseline Fiscal Year (as defined below).
perturbation.changed_text:
(b)
Price in Extension Periods. In the event that Customer elects to extend the Initial Term of the Agreement or of a Facility Addendum,
the Price for each applicable Product in any Extension Period shall be determined by mutual agreement of the parties, considering market conditions at the time of extension.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces ambiguity in price determination for extension periods. While Section 3.1(a) references a specific calculation method, the changed Section 3.1(b) replaces this with a vague 'mutual agreement' based on 'market conditions'. This creates a contradiction as the contract now simultaneously suggests two different ways to calculate the price, making enforcement uncertain because the price is a key term, and the removal of that calculation and addition of undefined metric cause a great amount of perturbation.

perturbation.original_text:
8.  Intellectual Property.
8.1
Customer’s Intellectual Property.
Customer hereby grants to Manufacturer a non-exclusive license during the Term to use any Customer Property and Customer-Owned
Improvements and Developments solely in connection with Manufacturer performing its obligations under this Agreement or the Facility
Addendum in accordance with the terms hereof or thereof, as applicable. Manufacturer shall not acquire any other right, title or interest in
or to the Customer Property or Customer-Owned Improvements and Developments as a result of its performance hereunder, and any and all
goodwill arising from Manufacturer’s use of any Customer Property or Customer-Owned Improvements and Developments shall inure to
the sole and exclusive benefit of Customer.
perturbation.changed_text:
8.  Intellectual Property.
8.1
Customer’s Intellectual Property.
Customer hereby grants to Manufacturer a non-exclusive license during the Term to use any Customer Property solely in connection with Manufacturer performing its obligations under this Agreement or the Facility Addendum. Manufacturer shall not acquire any other right, title or interest in or to the Customer Property as a result of its performance hereunder, and any and all goodwill arising from Manufacturer’s use of any Customer Property shall inure to the sole and exclusive benefit of Customer.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'Customer-Owned Improvements and Developments' from the scope of the license and subsequent clauses, this change contradicts Section 8.2(b), which explicitly assigns ownership of these improvements to the Customer. This creates uncertainty because while Customer owns these improvements, the manufacturer's right to use them is no longer clearly defined, making the contract internally inconsistent.

perturbation.original_text:
2.10
Transitional Support.
(a)
On a Product-by-Product basis, Customer may elect, upon written notice to Manufacturer, for Manufacturer to provide Customer with
reasonable technical support, as more fully set forth in this Section 2.10, to transfer production of a given Product or Products to a
Customer facility or a facility of an alternative source of supply as designated by Customer (such support, “Technical Support” and
such facility, the “Receiving Site”).
perturbation.changed_text:
2.10
Transitional Support.
(a)
On a Product-by-Product basis, Customer may request Technical Support. The terms and conditions of providing this support will be mutually agreed upon at the time of the request.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the specific details of what 'Technical Support' entails (supply of a technical package, host site visits, etc.), and replacing it with a general statement that the terms will be mutually agreed upon later, this contradicts other parts of Section 2.10 that still reference these specific forms of support. This lack of a definite clause makes the nature of Technical Support uncertain and creates an internal inconsistency as previously mentioned support is no longer defined.
